**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Had trouble getting up to speed with [Cypress](https://docs.cypress.io/guides/overview/why-cypress.html#In-a-nutshell) since there's currently no documentation on for how it's implemented in the code base.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I suggest we create a documentation page for Cypress that outlines how to:

- 1) run the tests locally and 
- 2) create end-to-end tests using Cypress whenever adding to the code base.

This section could potentially be under the ["Open a pull request"](https://contribute.freecodecamp.org/#/how-to-open-a-pull-request) section of "Code Contribution Guides".

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

A a link to the docs already on [cypress.io](https://docs.cypress.io/guides/overview/why-cypress.html#In-a-nutshell) could be added to the [introduction](https://contribute.freecodecamp.org/#/how-to-open-a-pull-request?id=how-to-open-a-pull-request-pr), but in my opinion this would probably be insufficient.

**Additional context**

- the PR where I created a Cypress test: #38806 
- Cypress.io [docs](https://docs.cypress.io/guides/overview/why-cypress.html#In-a-nutshell)


_ps: I'd love to give a PR for this a stab if it's decided it's needed._

This is a followup to a discussion I had with @RandellDawson in #35526 

As it stands, the guides for contributing to the coding challenges, their solution section in particular, are a little sparse.  For example, [How to work on coding challenges](https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/master/docs/how-to-work-on-coding-challenges.md) only shows a template with no solution.  [The Style guide](https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/master/docs/style-guide-for-curriculum-challenges.md), unsurprisingly, covers formatting, but not content.  

It might be worth clarifying that what has to go into a solution.  I managed to convince myself that all a solution needed to do was pass the tests, since that would allow the tests to be as fast as possible.  @RandellDawson pointed out that it's standard practice to base the solution on the full seed code and only make the modifications required to pass the tests.  i.e. that the solution should be one that a user is likely to come up with.  Could the documentation be changed to hammer this home?

#### Issue Description
A number of users setting up a local dev copy of freeCodeCamp have posted in Gitter with difficulties getting a working sign-up link using Mailhog.

The root cause seems to be the provided instructions are not clear enough. Specifically this line `To access your MailHog inbox, open your browser and navigate to http://localhost:8025. ` is being missed by users due to it appearing to be in the Linux specific setup instructions rather than applicable to all users.  

These users are therefore attempting to use a link copied out of the console window in which Mailhog is running. However this provides a `source` view of the email which is in an encoded form.

This means that a simple copy and paste into browser will fail as the encoded version has '=' replaced by '=3D' and soft line breaks (represented by an = symbol) inserted to keep line length below 76 characters.

Example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26827682/39624992-66fdb834-4f93-11e8-8ed0-a8896c70e4a2.png)

Additionally, it is possible they miss this entry in the console and try and pull a link out of further up the console output where the link is also polluted with end of line characters (eg \r\n) and the ampersand is represented in unicode - \u0026. 

Example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26827682/39625196-4bf52210-4f94-11e8-815f-8dac38eb16eb.png)

See also comment on issue #15838:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26827682/39625453-5db91622-4f95-11e8-8e64-3def4330ce48.png)

The solution is just to provide clearer instructions to ensure use of the MailHog WebUI, in which there is a  clickable link available in the plain text view provided. I've tested both 32bit and 64bit Mailhog executables on Win 7 and have confirmed behaviour is identical between the two versions.

#### Issue Description
There is a scenario where I raise a PR to my local copy of FreeCodeCamp instead of the Base Repository. 
If i merge my commits in the PR (since it is my local copy), my local fork of FCC gets the changes while the Base repository still remains unchanged.

**This can seem confusing (especially to First Timers), as it might seem to you that even though i made my changes, my changes are not getting updated in the Base Repository.**   


#### What needs to be updated ?

The updated instructions should be along the lines of : 

> Make sure that your **Base Fork** is set to **freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp** when raising a Pull Request

Thanks to @raisedadead , you can follow the instructions below to rewind the changes : 

> For fixing the head if accidental commits are made to the staging branch of ones own fork via pull-request, etc.:

> On your local machine
> 
> git checkout staging
> git fetch upstream staging
> git reset --hard upstream/staging
> git push --force origin staging
> 
> where your remotes [git remote -v] are:
> 
> origin	https://github.com/USERNAME/freeCodeCamp.git (fetch)
> origin	https://github.com/USERNAME/freeCodeCamp.git (push)
> upstream	https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp.git (fetch)

This is a continuation of [this discussion](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors?at=58b459bc4150746b151525c9) about how to use labels for PRs.

Instead of using the `blocked` label for PRs that have been reviewed but need further changes, we concluded that something like `changes requested` could be more friendly towards contributors than the `blocked` label.

If we want to make this change, we probably want to add this to the moderator guidelines or labeling guide.
